front.title: The Use of Non-ASCII Characters in RFCs

note.title: Requirements Language
note.t: The key words "MUST", "MUST NOT", "REQUIRED", "SHALL", "SHALL NOT", "SHOULD", "SHOULD NOT", "RECOMMENDED", "MAY", and "OPTIONAL" in this document are to be interpreted as described in RFC 2119.

section.title: Introduction
section.t: For much of the history of the RFC Series, the character encoding used has been US-ASCII. This was a sensible choice at the time: the language of the Series is English, a language which only uses US-ASCII-encoded characters (ignoring for a moment words borrowed from more richly decorated alphabets). US-ASCII is the "lowest common denominator" for character encoding, making cross-platform viewing trivial.

There are limits to US-ASCII, however, which hinder its continued use as the exclusive character encoding for the Series. The increasing need for easily readable, internationalized content suggests it is time to allow non-ASCII characters in RFCs where necessary. Given the contuinuing goal of maximum readability across platforms, the use of non-ASCII should not be gratuitous in a document. This RFC describes the rules under which non-ASCII characters may be used in an RFC. These rules will be applied as the necessary changes are made to submission checking and editorial tools.

section.title: Rules for the use of non-ASCII characters
General usage throughout a document
section.t: Non-ASCII characters may be used where appropriate, but where mentioned, the U+ identifier must be included.
Normalization forms: If the normalization matters to the content, the authors must submit in a normalization-resistant form. Do not expect normalization forms to be preserved.

section.title: Author Names
section.t: Valid Unicode is required, and for non-ASCII names, an ASCII-only identifier is required.

section.title: Body of the document
section.t: Body: Require identifiers, encourage characters, allow unicode names.

section.title: Tables
section.t: Tables: Tables follow the same rules for identifiers and characters as the body. If it is sensible (i.e., more understandable for a reader) for a given document to have two tables, one including the identifiers and characters, one with just the characters, that will be allowed on a case by case basis.

section.title: Code components
section.t: U+ except within a code component where you must follow the rules of the programming language in which you are writing the code

section.title: Bibliographic text
section.t: Bibliographic text: The reference must point to something that has been translated to English; there must be at least an English language title and author. This applies to both normative and informative references.

section.title: IANA Considerations
section.t: This document makes no request of IANA.
Note to RFC Editor: this section may be removed on publication as an RFC.
